title: Good job Riot! We asked, you answered. You gave us...DIVERSITY!
body:
Think about it, {{summoner:4}}/{{summoner:12}} isn't the be-all-end-all choice for toplane anymore. You can take {{summoner:4}}, {{summoner:11}}, {{summoner:14}}, {{summoner:12}} , or {{summoner:6}}! Riot has achieved their goal, there are more champions being played in the LCS than there ever were; we're seeing {{champion:6}} (Mid/ADC), {{champion:110}}  (MID), {{champion:69}} (top), {{champion:102}} (top), {{champion:24}} , {{champion:101}} , and {{champion:60}}! Smite doesn't just have to be taken by Junglers, THAT was a lack of diversity. We complained in 5.4 that there was no variety, that {{champion:254}}, {{champion:59}}, {{champion:64}}, and {{champion:421}} were the only worthwhile picks in the Jungle. Now that Riot has kept those champions viable WHILE opening up possibilities NEVER explored before, are we really going to complain? We got what we wanted, so please don't let Riot lose all hope in its fanbase. Learn to be grateful for what you wished for, because it's here.

League has finally become what I've wanted for so long, a game where almost any pick is viable. I can play Skarner and not get flamed, Amumu and not be irrelevant, and Rek'Sai to be a tank OR assassin/fighter. Riot, if you're reading this, you did right by me. Don't let the complainers influence you. Those who truly enjoy the game will commend you on your successes and suggest how to fix any shortcomings. May Season 5 be known as the time that Riot, the LCS, and loyal fans finally created a thing called Diversity.

**_BRAVO!_**

We've been really excited to see the gains to champion diversity over the past couple of months too --- by focusing on making more champions viable within each position and role, we're hoping to foster the fun sense of experimentation where players can find new champions they want to try out... or position... or role... or build... or strategy. 

We want to remove the oppressive champions and items who are overshadowing other options, and look for opportunities to carve out a more unique or special space for champions who may not stand out within the rest of the champion roster today. And all the while we'll continue to look forward to the next new and creative innovations that we know you all will make using those tools in ways we expect (and ways we don't).

Considering that a lot of what the pro players do is what sets the standard (since apparently League players make up a lot of the viewership for LCS/pro streams/etc.), I'd say that yeah, what they do is kind of important--maybe not for the best reasons, but it's tough to deny. Many players who take League seriously (or at least really, really like winning) tend to learn by watching people who are the best at what they do, and what they do influences those they play with and against. That, and with how much Riot is pushing eSports, they're pretty much always either on the launcher or the main client page.

They may only be 100 or so players, but they have the spotlight.

Riot has begun to deliver on their promise of greater competitive diversity, but your tone here worries me--it seems a lot like "things are starting to get better, so you shouldn't continue to criticize Riot on the current state of their game". 

Riot's finally made a nice step (compared to the S4 competitive scene, where you could guess off-hand just about every champion that would be picked or banned more than once), but they still have a long way to go. I think right now is a good time to stop and take a deep breath, appreciate the atmosphere, but not long enough to let complacency set in. 

Has League reached a state of perfect competitive balance? Are current champions viable for the right reasons (unique and strategy-defining niches, compared to "well, Urgot's ult can counter Zed even though it makes no sense with the rest of his kit")? As someone who watches as much competitive DotA as I do, I'm going to have to say that while the progress that League has been making is good, it's not as good as it could be--and that until then, it's important to stay critical.
